weapons:
notes: aa= anti-aircraft strength (in effect, the firing accuracy. This sort of data is scarce and heavily estimated.) alt= anti-aircraft altitude: L or H xrate= kg/min nominal maximum firing rate ap= anti-personnel strength (in effect, the efficiency of maximum fire rate) Because anti-personnel weapons either use bullets or explosive charges, there is less clear-cut a relation between rate of fire and anti=personnel efficiency. Mortars are assumed to be relatively inaccurate (as are rockets). There is some question about the efficiency of riflemen versus machine guns. The tables below assume that the rifleman is taken as the value 1 and all other values derive from this factor. armor= armor rating (compares with atpen) - same scale as atpen at= anti-tank strength (in effect, the firing accuracy combined with the number of shots available per minute. The issue of rate of fire takes into account the fact that heavier weapons reloaded more slowly, where the chance of a hit is really a function of the number o fshots on target. The atpen factor will tend to cancel out the rate when using small caliber weapons against heavily armored targets. (Accuracy data is scarce and heavily estimated.) Remember that this factor is multiplied by the rate to produce a total number of hit points. Thus, a small caliber gun may have a high at factor, a low rate and a low atpen so that it would compare favorably with a heavy gun when shooting at lightly armored targets like APC's, but would be reduced to insignificance against a heavily armored target such as a IS II or a Panther. atpen= anti-tank penetration (at 500 meters, against homogeneous armor) one of: 1 >=10mm @ 30 front hull armor 2 >=20mm @ 30 front hull armor 3 >=30mm @ 30 front hull armor 4 >=40mm @ 30 front hull armor 5 >=50mm @ 30 front hull armor 6 >=60mm @ 30 front hull armor 7 >=70mm @ 30 front hull armor 8 >=80mm @ 30 front hull armor 9 >=100mm @ 30 front hull armor 10 >=120mm @ 30 front hull armor 11 >=140mm @ 30 front hull armor 12 >=170mm @ 30 front hull armor 13 >=200mm @ 30 front hull armor 14 >=250mm @ 30 front hull armor ceil= Aircraft ceiling in meters altitude class= Weapon class, one of: aa Anti-aircraft weapon (towed or sp) afv Armored fighting vehicle arecce Reconnaissance aircraft art Artillery piece (towed or sp) at Anti-tank gun bomb Bomber aircraft ftr Fighter aircraft hvy Heavy weapon inf Infantry weapon mort Mortar ship Surface boat / ship spec Specialist sub Submarine veh Vehicle (non-armored) country=Country of manufacture / design crew= number of men included manning weapon desc= Description, model of weapon fuel= kilometers of road travel / ton of fuel consumed - offroad fuel consumption typically 50% greater fuelCap=liters of fuel held ammoCap=tons of ammunition held load= Bomb load capacity of bomber aircraft / hauling capacity of vehicle, train or aircraft name= Name used in referring to weapon (must be unique) carr= Carrier (foot, horse, bicycle, motorcycle, 2wd, 4wd, etc.) - default is foot range= Range in kilometers of indirect fire artillery or aircraft xrate= Consumption of ammunition in nominal kg/day - note that actual rate of fire depends on doctrine, available supply, intensity of combat, etc. speed= Air speed of aircraft tow= Can tow light (lt) or heavy (hvy) towed equipment towed= Can be towed and is light (lt) or heavy (hvy) wt= system weight, including full crew in metric tons
special attributes:
commissar Political / propaganda officer doctor Medical doctor eng Combat engineer general General jroff Junior officer (Captain) medic Medical aide / nurse mine Mining ability railrepair Rail repair crew radio Radio sroff Senior officer (Major - Colonel) svc Service / support personnel tankrepair Tank repair crew telephone Telephone
Rate, ap, aa, and at ratings. The weapon fire rate times the strength rating gives the net nominal firepower of the weapon. However, weapons can consume ammunition far faster than factories can produce it and trains can deliver it to the weapon. Also, tactical doctrine will dramatically influence the rate of fire (by reducing it from the nominal rate).
The following weapons list includes most models that saw service for the combatants. In a few cases, similar models have been combined, however, sources refer to numerous models which were created in limited numbers and which have not been included here so far for lack of reliable information about the model. I've found that no one source can be considered definitive.
